immediate_fixes.description: Hardcoded secrets, merge conflict markers, and incomplete code in critical paths. These expose credentials and break code execution.

examples.description: Simplistic detection logic for secrets may allow leaks and false positives.

immediate_fixes.description: Unresolved git merge conflict markers, incomplete code blocks, inconsistent logic. These prevent builds and runtime operation.

phase_1_high_priority.description: High-risk security flaws like dangerous functions, command injection, plaintext secrets, unsafe deserialization.
Bugs that may cause runtime failure, data loss, or security exposure.

phase_2_medium_priority.description: Code smells, anti-patterns, inconsistent logic, maintainability issues.

phase_3_low_priority.description: Documentation gaps, docstring improvements, comments, inline explanations.

safe_to_automate: Detection and removal of hardcoded secrets using improved scanning tools (subject to review)
Generic code quality improvements (e.g., unused imports, whitespace)
requires_review: Refactoring incomplete code blocks (e.g., incomplete with open statements)
Resolving merge conflicts (requires human decision on logic)
Replacing dangerous function usage (exec/eval) with safer alternatives
Credential management (moving secrets to environment variables or secret managers)

manual_fixes: All critical security issues (hardcoded secrets, command injection, unsafe deserialization)
Custom error handling and exception classes

multi_agent_candidates.rationale: Security-sensitive logic requires deep analysis and may benefit from specialized agents for detection and remediation.
Automated agent can assist but human review is necessary for final decision.
Automated linting and code formatting are safe for most code quality issues.
Automated documentation improvement is low risk and can be ongoing.

phase_1_critical.name: Critical Security & Bugs
actions: Remove all merge conflict markers and resolve code blocks with human review.
Replace or securely store hardcoded secrets using environment variables or secret managers.
Refactor incomplete code blocks and test for correctness.

phase_2_high_priority.name: High Priority Security & Bugs
actions: Update dangerous function detection logic to use AST and block usage in CI/CD.
Refactor credential handling (plaintext, hardcoded paths) to use secure storage.
Sanitize/desanitize shell commands, use SFTP for file writing.
Improve exception handling and expand detection for bare excepts.

phase_4_low_priority.name: Documentation & Minor Issues
actions: Add usage examples and module documentation.

low_risk_automated: Removal of merge conflict markers (if reviewed)
medium_risk_review: Refactoring code blocks with incomplete logic
high_risk_manual: Merge conflict resolution requiring context-sensitive business logic decisions
Security fixes involving secrets, shell commands, and external system integration
Changes to notification ID generation logic or other core subsystems

quick_wins: Automated removal of merge conflict markers

recommendations.recommended_approach: Use automation for safe, low and medium risk fixes (linting, docstrings, merge marker removal). Employ multi-agent systems for semi-automated review of security, merge conflict, and dangerous code. Human review required for business logic, security-sensitive changes, and merge conflict resolution.
warnings: Automated removal of merge markers must be followed by human logic reconciliation.
Credential migration requires review to avoid disruption of integrations.
Refactoring dangerous functions may break backward compatibility.
Always test after every phase; security fixes may introduce regressions.
next_steps: Form a triage team for critical fixes.
Run automated linting and conflict marker removal tools.
Assign multi-agent systems for security and code quality issue detection.
Schedule human review for merge conflicts and sensitive code paths.
Document all changes and create regression test suites.
